dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, uh, I hear 3D printing is officially dead. Like, totally done.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, uh, I hear 3D printing is officially dead. Like, totally done.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: So far this year, 3-D printing companies have attracted $400 million in venture funding, half the $800 million they had garnered in the entirety of last year, and surpassing the $300 million they'd attracted the year before that, according to the PitchBook analysis.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Whoa, wait, that's, like, actually super wrong. It's, um, exploding right now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Whoa, wait, that's, like, actually super wrong. It's, um, exploding right now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: So far this year, 3-D printing companies have attracted $400 million in venture funding, half the $800 million they had garnered in the entirety of last year... If deal flow continued at that rate, it would cross the billion-dollar mark for the first time in five years, even before accounting for the Carbon deal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exploding how? Like, in popularity, or in, uh, actual explosions? Cause I only care about the second one.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exploding how? Like, in popularity, or in, uh, actual explosions? Cause I only care about the second one.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, no actual explosions. But, um, venture capital. Carbon? They're getting another three hundred million.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, no actual explosions. But, um, venture capital. Carbon? They're getting another three hundred million.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That's the case even before accounting for the coming $300 million fundraise from 3-D printing unicorn Carbon, which was first reported by PitchBook on Thursday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Three hundred million? For what? More weird little plastic things?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Three hundred million? For what? More weird little plastic things?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, not just plastic. This year, uh, 3D printing companies already pulled in $400 million. That's, like, halfway to last year's total in just a few months.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, not just plastic. This year, uh, 3D printing companies already pulled in four hundred dollars million. That's, like, halfway to last year's total in just a few months.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: So far this year, 3-D printing companies have attracted $400 million in venture funding, half the $800 million they had garnered in the entirety of last year, and surpassing the $300 million they'd attracted the year before that, according to the PitchBook analysis.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Huh. $400 million. Still sounds like chump change compared to, like, literally anything else. Health tech, software, whatever.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Huh. four hundred dollars million. Still sounds like chump change compared to, like, literally anything else. Health tech, software, whatever.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While those dollars are a pittance compared to the funding numbers for healthcare or software companies, they represent a big bump up for 3-D printing, which has been gaining adoption in the industrial sector and has spawned hundreds of new startups.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, yeah, it's not healthcare numbers, but it's a massive bump for them. Like, back in 2014, it was only $100 million for the whole year. This Carbon deal is gonna be the biggest ever.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, yeah, it's not healthcare numbers, but it's a massive bump for them. Like, back in twenty fourteen, it was only one hundred dollars million for the whole year. This Carbon deal is gonna be the biggest ever.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 2014, for example, 3-D printing companies attracted just $100 million in VC funding, according to the PitchBook analysis. Carbon's $300 million fundraise would be the largest deal of the past five years among 3-D printing companies, according to the PitchBook analysis, surpassing the same firm's earlier $200 million deal in February 2018.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: The biggest ever? For, uh, 3D printing? Big whoop.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The biggest ever? For, uh, 3D printing? Big whoop.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, but seriously. They're valued at $1.7 billion, might hit $2.5 billion. They could actually overtake Stratasys, the market leader.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, but seriously. They're valued at one point seven dollars billion, might hit two point five dollars billion. They could actually overtake Stratasys, the market leader.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company is currently valued at $1.7 billion, and could be worth as much as $2.5 billion after the new funding.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Stratasys? Is that, like, a transformer? I don't know any of these names.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Stratasys? Is that, like, a transformer? I don't know any of these names.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's a huge deal. And, um, like, three of the top ten deals in five years just happened in the first few months of this year. Desktop Metal, Markforged...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a huge deal. And, um, like, three of the top ten deals in five years just happened in the first few months of this year. Desktop Metal, Markforged...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Three of the top 10 deals of the past five years have occurred in the first few months of this year, according to the PitchBook analysis: Metal 3-D printer maker Desktop Metal raised $160 million, reaching a valuation of $1.5 billion; Markforged, which makes 3-D printers for carbon and metal, raised $82 million, hitting a valuation of $820 million; and 3-D printing service provider Fast Radius brought in $48 million, reaching a valuation of $400 million.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so people are throwing money at it. But what are they doing with it? Still just toys?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so people are throwing money at it. But what are they doing with it? Still just toys?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No! Think Adidas. Carbon's making the midsoles for their Futurecraft 4D shoes. And they're talking about doing entire shoe models now, just, like, printing them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No! Think Adidas. Carbon's making the midsoles for their Futurecraft 4D shoes. And they're talking about doing entire shoe models now, just, like, printing them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Carbon is best known for its partnership with Adidas, with whom it is partnering on midsoles for the German sportswear giants Futurecraft 4D running shoes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Shoes. Okay. So instead of, uh, getting shoes from a factory, you get them from a printer. Revolutionary.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Shoes. Okay. So instead of, uh, getting shoes from a factory, you get them from a printer. Revolutionary.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It is revolutionary! It speeds up production so much! And Google's venture arm, Alphabet, they're investing. Sequoia, GE, Adidas Ventures...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It is revolutionary! It speeds up production so much! And Google's venture arm, Alphabet, they're investing. Sequoia, G E, Adidas Ventures...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Redwood City, California-based company counts Sequoia, GV, Fidelity, General Electric and Adidas Ventures among its existing investors.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alphabet? Like, the company that sells ads? Okay, that's, uh, slightly less boring. I guess.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alphabet? Like, the company that sells ads? Okay, that's, uh, slightly less boring. I guess.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: See? It matters! It's growing! It's not just trinkets anymore!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: See? It matters! It's growing! It's not just trinkets anymore!
